reviewText: Pony Island is interesting, and probably worth a play if you're an exploratory gamer and you're out of new stuff to play. That said, I wouldn't really call it good. I can't really be too specific without spoiling anything, but it boils down to a couple hours of interactive narrative with some mostly dull gameplay segments. The humor is pretty amusing, and there's some neat dramatic moments, but for a game whose main selling point is its meta-ness, the story has a surprising lack of depth or significance. But hey, give the dev another couple hundred years and this game could really be something special!

reviewText: A distracting little title, but I expected more layers. Under the pretense of a suspence/horror game, pony island is actually extremely linear and streightforward. Peering deeper into the machine might net you a few achivements but it doesn't change anything about the story or gameplay. Even the story itself is completely face-value - once you get the basic premise, you've seen it all. 4th wall breaks were entertaining but gimmicky. Nothing has lasting impact.\n\nI'm giving this a thumbs down in spite of myself because it's only 5 bucks and probably is worth playing, but compared to other games or to what it *could* have been, it doesn't make par. I'd be interested to see it improve if the developer keeps going - there's a lot of unexplored material to expand on, and it could be really excellent given more time and more levels into the conspiracy.

reviewText:
I really do like the premise of this game- the sort of meta-puzzle you don't see very often. It's good fun, and always interesting, because it supercedes the game's mechanical limitations as to what the puzzles can be.

What I can't look past, however, is that during the two hours or so it took me to beat the game, I was unbelievably bored a good half of it. The game's insistence on the game within the game heavily overstayed its welcome, even though that might've been the point. Still, it was tedious, and I'd rather have done something else during those times, the pony game and the key puzzles.

Interesting premise, but ultimately not that satisfying as an experience.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Pony Island is an unusual puzzle and gallery shooter game that's fairly meta, but not nearly as intelligent as it wants you to believe it is.

My experience with Pony Island was not very thrilling.  I was bored throughout most of it.  I spent the first hour or two trudging onwards, telling myself that all the cool stuff was going to start happening eventually, and I just had to wait it out.  Before long, though, I realized that that wasn't the case—that the repetitive pony shooter really was all there was to see here.  There's some ticket-collecting gimmick here for all of the virtual crack addicts, but not much of substance—nothing that really makes you laugh, or feel things, or stop and reflect, like a good indie game would, nor is there much of a challenge.  It's just kind of... a thing that you experience.

With that, I'm left wondering what the game's appeal was supposed to be.  It's not really funny—I think I laughed a sum total of once—it's not really witty, and the music doesn't do much for me.  The game is embellished with a few meta-heavy gimmicks and a narrative of the game is possessed by an evil force that is being a jerk to you"
date: but the bulk of the "gameplay" is split between a gallery shooter with a laser-shooting pony
recommended: and some "put the right item in the right place at the right time" puzzles.  With slight variations
hoursPlayed: you'll go through the same kinds of puzzles and shooter stages over and over
voteText: for bulk of the 3 hours of the game.  With regards to this
helpfulPercent: I think it fair for me to summarize the game as being a one-trick pony.  (Hah!  Get it?  My joke is almost as clever as the game itself.)\n\nOn the positive side of things
votesHelpful: the game is competent.  Stylistically
votesTotal: in terms of graphics and sound
votesFunny: it nails the atmosphere that it's going for.  However
commentsCount: style doesn't cut it for me; I'm looking for subtance
column16: and I found Pony Island lacking in that category.\n\nAnother positive: There was one boss "fight" that I thought was kind of neat
column17: and some of the meta stuff happening there really took me off-guard.  But that's just 10-15 minutes of the game.  I spent the rest in boredom.\n\nLastly
column18: the game is only $5.  This is a plus
column19: because if it looks like the sort of thing that would appeal to you
column20: despite my negative view of it
column21: you're not putting a whole lot on the line to buy it and see for yourself.\n\nIn closing
column22: there's a lot of hype surrounding this game right now
column23: but I don't think that it's warranted.  Pony Island is simply a repetitive game with very little to say.  I think people lauding this game as an early contender for GotY 2016 are gravely mistaken
column24: as I doubt that anyone will remember this game come the end of the year
column25: much less 5 or 10 years from now

column27: I don't recommend spending your time on Pony Island."

reviewText:
With all the overwhelming reviews for this title, along with the promise of psychological horror got me really interested, but playing this in the first place was quite the mistake

The game progressive at an alarming rate and becomes stale pretty quicky. The attempt at horror is just terrible, this game hasn't offered me any of that good old paranoia that a game of it's type promises. The dialogue feels rushed and it leaves no impact on me at all. The hacking bits were nice, but became somewhat boring and it didn't give me the degrees of freedom as I expected it to. The story seemed to have been alterable at first glance, but it's all in a fine line, everything along it, you see coming. This feels like nothing more than an flash game with a price tag, and that's what upsets me most.

I'm going to see if I can refund this, don't be fooled by the massive amount of short and undetailed positive reviews.

reviewText:
Yeah so, uh.... Pony Island was kinda boring. I'm really surprised it'd gotten SO many positive reviews and that makes me feel like i've missed something? I've looked around on the net and watched videos and I didn't see much that I didn't see while I was playing it except a really uninteresting hidden boss at the end.

I honestly try my best to find something likable or at least interesting in any of the media I consume so it took me a while to really formulate an opinion on this one, but after turning it over in my head for a couple days i'm not left with much favorable to say.

Right away the take something cute but make it all uhh... dark and stuff" theme wasn't too promising
date: but I saw a lot of potential in the "satanic game" idea and the graphic style gave neat atmosphere that really worked for a while.  I spent the whole game waiting for it to realize this potential into something greater but it never delivered. I guess it's a horror-comedy but it's neither scary nor funny. For as hard as it was trying to be clever
recommended: it caught me off guard maybe twice in the two hours it took me to complete it and the entire trajectory of the game felt really obvious. I don't really like games that try to be clever above all else anyway. It make the whole game feel substanceless.\n\nThe thing that bothers me the most tho is that it doesn't even have much in the way of engaging gameplay to fall back on. There's basically two game-types you switch between
hoursPlayed: one being a really underdeveloped action runner and the other being essentially a pipe puzzle dressed up to look like a coding game. Both get really repetative.\n\nThere's an earlier browser version of this game from 2014 that takes maybe two minutes to play. It's really stripped down compared to this. No real story

reviewText:
An extremely predictable LP/stream bait game. The plot is akin to a generic creepy pasta, so it doesn't scratch pretty deep to begin with. Thematically, it just jumps straight into being unsettling, leaving no real surprise when it becomes more and more satanic as the game progresses. The attempts to include biblical references are also pretty sloppy. This may come from the game being unsure if it's supposed to be funny or spooky. The music is pretty good, but equally as repetitive.

As you can probably assume from the screenshots, the gameplay is rubbish. You jump over hurdles and shoot your lazer. It never really gets difficult in any way, in that you have infinite tries in every single situation, including the final and secret final bosses.
The puzzle sections of the game are somewhat interesting in concept, being a sort of sequence puzzle, but it expects the player to be dumb as a stump and never pushes the complexity past a few minutes of trial and error.

In a game about breaking the 4th wall, it doesn't do enough with that concept. I expected a lot more player interaction but in the end I found the game was just funneling my choices by barring me from siding with the satanic voice comming from inside the game. For example, at one point in the game you are forced to cheat in order to get a lazer beam, but soon after the satan voice tells you to turn off the cheat. I tried to, to see if I could for some extra dialogue and the game had disabled the option to. It's things like this which turn a 4th wall breaking experience into an on the rails no fun allowed snorefest.
The only part that actually caught me by surprise was asmodeus making skype sounds and steam notifications pop up. I would love to see more things like that, where the fail state is a little more obscure and open ended than just dieing in a minigame and having to restart.

Basically, don't buy it unless you're a markiplier clone.

1/666

reviewText: I found this game really frustrating and not in a good way. I bought it because it looked like an interesting puzzle solver and had lots of good reviews and although parts of it are good. (The interactive bits between the player and the entities in the machine are quite well done) most of the game involves running the same linear pony run over and over and over which gets tedious. I might even have been able to cope with that but there seems to be a few bugs. One involves sometimes the lazer going off instead of jumping with the left mouse button (I even started using my left and right hand to press the buttons to make sure I wasn't accidently hitting the wrong ones by mistake but no joy there), and the other popped up as sin desert where when you do the large stream of lazer sometimes it takes a second or two after you lift your finger off the button to stop the lazer from working.....by which stage you've died because you were meant to jump. (You don't seem to be able to start a jump with the lazer going). That means you go right back to the beginning and have to run the same linear jump and fire game over and over until you manage to get through despite the glitches. Maybe it's because I'm using a trackpad. I wasn't aware the game said to use a mouse not a trackpad until I'd already bought it and since I don't own a mouse the trackpad's all I've got (Worth bearing in mind if you're a laptop only user like me). Sorry nice idea but can't recommend.

reviewText: A clever game that actively resists attempts to play it. reviewText:
While this game is interesting, it suffers from a few fatal flaws.

Firstly, it is very short, you can blaze through it in less than an hour.
Secondly, it borrows from undertale, the same way leatherface borrows people.  It is the same down to the minute details of having a character teach you stuff, name ends with -ey and introduces himself by saying howdy!
And finally, while visually interesting, it just is unfun and not good on the story front.  I would buy this for mabye 0.99 and that is a bit much.

(and I wasn't lying about the undertale thing, its ending is the same, down to the dialog.  One of the bossfights does the samething a boss does in undertale, and it even uses old retro gameplay to put a 'spin' on the boring combat/platforming)

reviewText:
This game is not as clever as it thinks it is.

There are 3 gameplay modes: exploring Satan's computer, solving puzzles, and platforming. The exploration is so forcibly linear that it can barely be called exploration; you just click on everything until you proceed. The puzzles are simple and easy. The platforming is intentionally bad, which is foolish, because it's a significant chunk of the game.

Story is your reward for slogging through the intentionally bad platforming. But the story is also simple, and you will guess most of the plot twists. There is some kind of thematic commentary about how mobile games and endless runners are like being trapped in Hell
date: but the critique falls flat when the game just IS the very thing it's trying to criticize.\n\nThere's some talent here, but it's wasted on cynicism.

reviewText:
While I would say that Pony Island is interesting and worth experiencing, I find it hard to recommend it for the 5Euro it asks for.

The gameplay consists of three sets of mechanics.

*puzzles where you manipulate the route of an arrow through the game's code. increasing or decreasing values to unlock new abilities or progress the story.

*Making your way through computer interfaces, communicating with the characters of the game.

*A side scrolling runner where you jump over obstacles, and defeat enemies,using a rechargeable beam.

The puzzles are interesting and bring some well balanced enjoyment. While the runner stages feel more like a chore, that you endure for the sake of progressing the story.

The story and aesthetics is what redeems the game. What they do with the puzzles, and the way they connect the story with the fact that you are inside an old computer is interesting to say the least. It doesn't leave much to the imagination, but makes you pounder what computer games can be.


This said, it is a 2.5 hour game, that consists a lot of running in a straight line, jumping obstacles. If you see this on a sale, grab it, but for the current price of €5, It's a thumbs down.

Pros:
+Interesting puzzles
+Unexpected Twists
+Great Atmosphere

Cons:
-Boring runner segments
-Unclear objectives
-short
-Unsatisfactory ending, the last fight didn't in any way show if what you were doing was progressing the battle, leaving you just running and beaming things seemingly at random.

reviewText: I'm going to be completely honest here, I did not enjoy my time at all with Pony Island. Before I go into a rant, listen, I find the concept and its art design incredibly good, the game messes with you in such a way that you want to keep on playing, it's just a shame that the gameplay itself isnt very good. Pony Island goes into two main forms of gameplay, the infinite pony runner and the code puzzles, sadly both of these will end up wearing on your patience rather quicky as the infinite runner is just that, and the puzzles get frustrating to the point of soaking up most of the adventure without giving you much of a reason to enjoy them. This game is a sponge of repetition, new concepts do not come frequently, and for the most part all they are is just a visual effect with little variation. I can only recommend those who are extremely curious to try the game out, and hey if you find something in the game I didnt? Thats fine, enjoy the game, this is just my opinion after all.

reviewText:
I'm posting my final verdict of the game up here because the rest of the review is filled to the brim with spoilers.  Pick up this game.  It's short, sweet, and yet, somehow very involved with plenty of secrets.  In the playtime overall listed for me, I have 100% completed this game.  BUY IT!

Now then, on to the main review:

Allow me to be clear, this game is not entirely about ponies.  If you're considering it because ponies, look elsewhere.  If you're looking for a puzzle platformer that messes with your head, you should pick this up.

The game's story isn't flat out told to you, however there are clues if you know where to look.  You play as Theodore, a crusader who died and was sent to purgatory.  While there, you are forced to play a poorly programmed video game.  You recieve help from a hopeless soul, who is likewise trapped in the computer.  As you play, things deteriorate as you match wits with 1u(c)if#r, the programmer of (the In-Universe) Pony Island, and his 3 daemons (Incedently, I love that pun.  Well played Dan).

The game centers around 2 main concepts, the puzzles and the platforming.  Each of these is very well put together, and leads to an enjoyable gameplay experience.  The game is best played with a wired 2-3 button mouse, but you can also use Space and Right Alt (Option).  The puzzle difficulty is staggered very nicely and, with one notable exception, make you feel very smart when you solve them. (At least, that's my subjective view)

The visual style of this game is remenicent of DOS-era PC games, featuring a lot of vector-based artwork.  At least, at first.  One of the greatest things about this game is how it almost perfectly mirrors PC game advances, adding an overworld and eventually full 16-bit color graphics.  The music and sound design is also fantastic.  I purchased this game and the Soundtrack DLC, and both are worth the money.

This game has 24 tickets to collect and 20 achievements.  Be prepared once you get that 24th ticket though.  Once you do, you get whisked away to the true final boss, unless you are playing through the game for the first time, getting every ticket on the way.  Then you will have to wait until the end of the game.  This boss has 3 phases that reflect what you have learned in the platforming portions of the game.  While I'm talking about bosses, I should bring up the daemons.  The first one tests your puzzle skills.  The second one tests your platforming skills.  The third one messes with your head, and it is glorious.  It even tricked me once, and I knew it was coming!  I love when bosses break the 4th wall creatively, so this boss was a nice treat.

Overall, this game is amazing.  If you need another reason to pick up this game, just look for the 200+ post discussion in the community hub.  Give it a read, and you'll see just how much love went into this game.  This game gets my Seal of Recommendation.  GIVE IT A TRY, MORTAL.

reviewText:
Normally I don't give much attention to silly creepypasta-inspired games, but a friend gave it to me on day 1 as a belated Christmas gift and I decided to give it a try out of courtesy.

What I found was an interesting experience. After going through all this game has to offer, getting all of its achievements and finding all of its secrets (or so I think), I'm not entirely sure if I have played the game or if the game has played me. Like a freaking fiddle. This game will try its darnedest to surprise you by shifting graphical style, gameplay and even tone constantly. It also contains 4th wall breaking moments that will catch you off-guard unless you tackle the game spoilered about them.

That said, while it will give you quite a few surprises, its gameplay is not really anything to write home about. It simply does the job. It also has a few frustrating moments. You're gonna need a bit of patience to deal with this game.

This is not a masterpiece, but it is an entertaining game that will subvert your expectations and train you to keep on the look for surprises and secrets. If you have the money to spare and nothing else in your back catalogue with a higher priority, you should give it a try.

reviewText: I buy indie titles sometimes if they look interesting, and usually I end up disappointed.  Pony Island not only looks interesting, it IS interesting.  Fascinating in fact.  More story than an action game, more action than an adventure game, and pulls some very clever tricks that genuinely makes you wonder what's game and what's reality.  One playthrough doesn't take very long, but one playthrough isn't the end of it - for myself I'm positive I'll be going back to find out the rest of the story.  For the price it's a must play game.

reviewText:
Pony Island is an Indie, Puzzle game that isn't about ponies. It was a very fun, pretty short, and VERY difficult game, that I enjoied playing.

In Pony Island, the Devil, Lucifer, has trapped your soul in a game he made called Pony Island. With the help of, someone, I don't know his name, you are on a mission to escape. It is a very dark game, I will say that. There are 3 core files you must destroy in order to escape, and each is guarded by a Daemon. The game itself has about two controls: Left click and right click. And, no, I'm not making that up. the game makes you think, and it tricks you. It is also creepy at times, say, when, one of your freinds starts Steam messaging you, but actually isn't.

Overall, it is a good game. I do recommend, and it is one of those cheaper games on Steam. Just, if you are a Christian, I suggest you stay away from this game. No offense.

reviewText:
Downloaded this game out of curiosity, booted it up then 4 hours later realized I was still playing it, not the longest game in the world as I said I beat it in just under 4 hours, but never boring, has a great story and a really satisfying difficulty curve.

Playing through this game I had a the same feeling of drive to beat it I had the first time I played Portal, the game twists and turns and is always interesting and surprising, really compelling world building and made me want to play through a second time to see what I missed. It also has a fantastic retro soundtrack that keeps you in the groove.

Very Meta game and always has you guessing, genuinely made me laugh at points and one of the best games story driven games I have played in years.
A breath of fresh air in this world of big budget, blockbuster games with 4000 people on the dev team and $15,000,000,000 in the bank.
A real master class in what can be done with talent and passion, not just millions of dollars.

Fantastic game a defiant must play

reviewText: A new genre/mechanic has been born since games like Frog Fractions or maybe Candy Box. I'd call it Evolving Deception Puzzle" (EDP) mechanic and it requires excellent development to really interest someone into what seems to be a broken game at first glance. It's still a new genre and requires adding elements of gameplay that will go against mainstream development
date: that's why it will be difficult to grasp by high budget studios. That didn't stop Daniel Mullins Games when developing this piece of art (yes I consider videogames an artform) and they executed it very well. The retro-gaming style is always challenging the trend of overwhelming graphics
recommended: effects and complexity with smart simplicity and creativity. In this regard Pony Island excels in creativity and it's simple in some aspects while complex in others.\n\nPony Island shows exactly what the genre is about
hoursPlayed: taking elements from all known gaming mechanichs and arranging them into a way that creates a totally different thing. Certainly not a perfect game in all aspects
voteText: in my opinion it could look better and be more pleasant overall to the eye and ear while keeping the grim aspects and that can keep some players away. For me it isn't an issue and I'm glad for that but I reckon this game is not for everyone. Sadly this genre requires some gaming experience (since it mixes mechanics) and willingness to "play along" so I wouldn't suggest it to all my friends but I know there's some of them that will thank me after showing them this excellent game."

reviewText:
Overview: Edgy metafiction worth its price tag and a try.

Congrats! You're stuck in Pony Island forever. Not on Pony Island. In it.

That's literally the premise of the game. You're playing a game.... about being stuck in a game. The game made by probably the literal devil or..... something demonish like that.

The gameplay overall is repetitive. Most gameplay is jumping or doing a little puzzle, that's consistent. At least it lets you get used to it in that sense.

There are definitely some cool parts. This game has lots of homages to older games and genres, and there are some interesting scenes.

The plot itself is kind of forced. I really dig the premise, but I feel like it's trying too hard.

Pony Island's atmosphere is like if you walk through a front lawn on Halloween. A good scary lawn has some neat, creepy ambient effect, maybe with some music, fog, a few tombstones, and an animatronic or few. Pony Island is like the whole lawn is full of really interesting animatronics, but they're pretty cheesy and constantly moving, and it ruins the mood.

Don't get me wrong -- the implications of much of what happens in the game is really interesting. For instance - and the following isn't a spoiler" so much as it is something that's better to think about after you finish the game - it's slightly implied that every time you mess up
date: you die and you continue on as someone else. The game has its own world and lore that's pretty neat.\n\nBut if you're like me and can't stand "edge for the sake of edge
recommended: then the spiel gets a bit annoying fast. Especially the main character who guides you through.\n\nNow, I'm not saying this game isn't worth playing for that reason. I definitely think it's worth some time. It tackles gaming in a metafiction" sense -- that is
hoursPlayed: addressing itself as a game. The genre has a lot of opportunities for metafiction narrative
voteText: and this is one of the better shots at it. But if that's not your thing
helpfulPercent: then you're going to absolutely loathe it.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: Pony Island keeps you entertained the whole way through
votesTotal: but much like the souls in the machine
votesFunny: you might be just waiting for it all to be over.\n\nIs Pony Island worth it? I mean
commentsCount: why wouldn't you buy a $5 game? It's extremely good for its price tag. It's well-programmed and a fun challenge that'll take you on a journey. I'd say
column16: if you're still interested despite my long rambling
column18: March 10

reviewText: Think of this 4-hour narrative indie game like you would a movie ticket - five dollars up front for an evening of solid entertainment. Are all the meta gags groundbreaking for the medium? No - Portal, The Stanley Parable and Undertale all did it better. Still, you'll appreciate the labor of love that went into this project. It's a meta-game about game programming and development. Programmers, chipheads and vaporwave fans alike will appreciate all the subtle nods to Windows 95, Atari, Arcades, Nintendo, Programming, Creepypasta, Terrible Flash Games, and the myriad glitches inherent to all software.\n\nI do have one incredibly autistic nitpick that just bugged me, and that's the game's zeroes and ones" motif - actual base-2 binary dumps are usually abbreviated as base-16 hexadecimal strings because it's slightly more readable than the raw pulses read by machines. Every Hollywood hacker movie gets it wrong
date: though.\n\nPony Island is not without much bigger problems
voteText: wears out its welcome fast after just so many iterations. The two constant games at work here boil down to a flappy bird-esque timed rail jumper
helpfulPercent: and what can best be described as a programming minigame. None of the programming puzzles will make your head explode or require a particularly trained mind
votesHelpful: save for Louie's last "Puzzle Break"
votesTotal: which I found to be a massive difficulty spike requiring way too many steps and variables to juggle around - you practically need to draw out each step on graph paper. Maybe it's easier if you're well versed in programming or just have a really good memory
votesFunny: but the sheer difficulty of that last puzzle broke the game's pacing for me. I had to look up the solution on YouTube
commentsCount: and even following a walkthrough required me to write each step down over several grids. There's one last puzzle after that
column16: but it's essentially a breather. Still
column17: after wasting an hour on that last one
column18: I was NOT in the mood for any more programming puzzles. I guess your mileage may vary
column19: but I can't be alone in struggling with that one.\n\nAnother
column20: lesser thing that tripped me up was trying to guess a "Pay Attention and Remember This" riddle on the last Core. I simply was not listening for the solution the guardian gave out earlier
column21: and unfortunately it's given out right before a checkpoint when there's a lot of distractions going on
column22: so I had to look up the solution on YouTube
column23: again. Surely I can't be the only one who was caught off guard? How did this get by playtesters?! I get that it's supposed to test your mental savvy but this kind of 4-hour game really should be completable by the masses without having to break out a strategy guide. It's not a super-hardcore "git gud" game like Fighters

All gripes aside
column25: the ending was pretty cathartic - it left me satisfied for the evening I invested into it. Although before the final escape

column27: or if God was a greater evil than Satan pulling the strings a la Shin Megami Tensei

Don't let this game's one-trick pony wear itself out and negatively taint your memory of it through even more repetitious search for that last lousy point. This isn't necessarily a bad thing

reviewText: All I have to say is... damn. This game was an absolute adventure. The soundtrack is fantastic (and I've been listening to it nonstop ever since I completed the game!) The mood of the game was great, I love glitchy corrupted arcade stuff so this was right up my alley. There were awesome fourth-wall-breaking moments that seriously tricked me, and the puzzles were just the right level of difficulty.\nPony Island is an awesome and unforgettable experience. If you're prepared to be challenged, frustrated, messed with, confused, and maybe even afraid, this game is for you. No jumpscares, the game gets you psychologically.\nAlso, the ponies are cute.

reviewText:
I liked this game a lot. Its like nothing I've ever played before, and at a few points it actually sent chills down my spine. As far as gameplay goes, its pretty simple.

The main mechanic is just jumping over barriers, slowly gliding on wings, and shooting targets with lazers, and the levels are broken up by some puzzles involving logic gates.

The game is pretty short so it will depend on how quickly you can pick up on the puzzles and notice small details to make it through the menus, although there are many secrets and easter eggs scattered through the game to find. A full completion of the game should take around 2-3 hours.

Loved it, for $5 I'd say its deffinitely worth it.

reviewerDisplayName: Pun God McGee ~ #1 Kappa at TU
reviewText:
Usually when a game gets released during Q1 of the new year, there aren't high hopes for it succeeding due to the intense Q4 of the previous year with massive triple A titles coming out the cut and wanting all the attention. However, for Pony Island, this caught my attention after watching the Yogscast do a short episode about it. I was intrigued that some guy decided to make a game titled Pony Island.

But here's where I went wrong...

Pony Island isn't some happy go-lucky game where you control some person riding a pony and frolicking in the wilderness. It's a game where you know that the decisions you make impact you as the player and the character you are mimicking. When it comes to indie games, they love using dark themes because it provides that depth most games don't have. In Pony Island, there is no such thing as a linear story. There is reason behind each statement and it's a psychological thriller. Yes, clicking and shooting lazers is all fun and games, but when you are trying to secure your own freedom from the grasp of a devil like creature (Satan, in this case), you will do anything in your power to be freed from the oppression.

This is why I'm giving this game a definite 9.5/10. The story, art style, and music mesh really well together and gave me a positive experience despite the fact that some parts are really repetitive. I hope you guys enjoy the game as much as I did because man, this is one of the best games I've played so far that came out this year.

FULL RATING:
Story: 9.8/10
Gameplay: 9.4/10
Music: 9.5/10
Art: 9.2/10

reviewText:
I'm very mixed about this game. It has a lot of good features, which do make me recommend it, but a lot of features that also fall short.

First off, the game has nothing to do with ponies.

Pony Island is a glitch-horror game based around a single arcade machine (or computer.) It's a puzzle type game as well, and has a deep internal lore and meaning.

Pros
-Puzzles can be challenging
-Pretty a-ok music
-Fun stages
-A lot of fourth wall breaks

Cons
-2-3 hours long
-Can be hurtful on the eyes at 1 or 2 times
-Only a handful of characters, not necissarily a bad thing but I like more than 6 characters in games

Story - 7.5
Presentation - 9
Overall - 8.5

Opinion
Pony Island is a well-made and very clever game, with lots of tricks up it's sleeve that'll catch you off guard. A nice lore, but not a great story. A little on the short side of characters. As appealing as it is, it has it's flaws at many points. But I do recommend this to anyone that likes puzzle games or just clever games.
